description: From Middle English city, citie, citee, cite, from Old French cité, from Latin cīvitās (“citizenry; community; a city with its hinterland”), from cīvis (“native; townsman; citizen”), from Proto-Indo-European *ḱey- (“to lie down, settle; home, family; love; beloved”).
Cognate with Old English hīwan pl (“members of one's household, servants”). See hewe. Doublet of civitas.
Mostly displaced native Old English burg, whence Modern English burg.

entries.meaning: A large settlement, bigger than a town; sometimes with a specific legal definition, depending on the place.
examples: São Paulo is the largest city in South America.

entries.meaning: (UK) A settlement granted special status by royal charter or letters patent; traditionally, a settlement with a cathedral regardless of size.

examples: I'm going into the city today to do some shopping.

entries.meaning: (slang) A large amount of something (used after the noun).
examples: It’s video game city in here!
